conclusion: 100 µs between successive transmitted pulses corresponds to a 100 µs spacing on the time-base of the indicator.
The display shows the echo spike lying exactly in the middle of the two neighbouring transmission spikes (ab = bc).
The echo delay equals one half of the pulse-to-pulse interval: t_echo = ½ × 100 µs = 50 µs.
In that time the radar wave travels to the obstacle and back, so the one-way (radar-to-target) travel time is t_one-way = ½ × 50 µs = 25 µs.
Distance = c × t_one-way = 3.0 × 10⁸ m s⁻¹ × 25 × 10⁻⁶ s = 7.5 × 10³ m = 7.5 km.
